awd_titl_txt: Manipulating and Exploiting Lattice Strain as a Novel Platform to Tune the Surface Work Function of Metallic Nanocatalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description:

Lattice strain, arising from crystal imperfections, is an important phenomenon of material modification and can bring many novel advantages to catalysts as it changes the surface adsorption behavior through a variation of the catalyst surface work function. For noble metal-based ultra-small particles, that is, nanocrystals, manipulation of the lattice strain could be one of the significant pathways to improve their catalytic performance on chemical and electrochemical reactions. This project focuses on the study of the lattice strain existing in bimetallic nanocrystals that are produced via a gas-phase etching approach. One of the proposed materials is a Pt-Ni nanocrystal system from which the Ni-component is extracted by combining with carbon monoxide to form gaseous nickel carbonyl at a mild temperature, thus creating a strain in the nanocrystal. Through this lattice strain concept, the research aims to seek some fundamental understandings of the lattice strain formation and solutions of catalytic improvement in some emergent electrochemical reactions in energy conversion and environmental protection, such as reactions in fuel-cell, water-splitting, and carbon-neutral conversion. Specifically, this study will answer the following questions: How can the lattice strain be generated and controlled during a de-alloying process? How can the lattice strain be explicitly identified? And how can the lattice strain be used experimentally to promote the reactivity? This project will have profound impacts on various ongoing outreach and education programs through multidisciplinary research platform. The insights and knowledge gained from this study will stimulate the NSF-supported S-STEM program, Binghamton University's "Transdisciplinary Area of Excellence" campaign, and novel curriculum development. This project will also promote lab-based training activities of graduate and undergraduate students through summer research programs by forging links among diverse research fields. In addition, the success of this study will bring multifold benefits to the general public through scientific discoveries and resultant technologies.


Technical description:

For noble metal nanocrystals, lattice strain can generally cause a lattice contraction featuring a down-shift d-band center, which weakens the adsorption strength of species on the catalyst surfaces. The goal of this project is to significantly advance the development of catalytic sites with lattice strain that exists in several types of shape-controlled state-of-the-art nanocrystals as the model systems. The lattice-stressed systems can be created from Ni-containing bimetallic precursors by taking advantage of the Mond process as an unprecedented etching protocol. The related de-alloying mechanism will be understood in depth through a systematical structure-analysis of the highly porous nanoframes generated from a gaseous de-alloying process. With an evaluation of their electrocatalytic performance using several typical reactions including but not limited to ORR, HER, and eCO2RR, a comparison of the identified performances with and without the strain stress will be implemented, and a reactivity-strain correlation that provides guidelines for tuning electrocatalytic activity will be uncovered. The proposed Pt-Ni precursor will also be extended to other bimetallic systems, such as Cu-Ni, Ag-Ni, Pd-Ni, and Fe-containing bimetallic system. This project will have profound impacts on the exploitation of mechanistic origin of the catalytic activity as well as novel insights of the electrocatalytic performance improvement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: State University of New York at Binghamton

por.por_cntn:
Lattice strain, resulting from crystal imperfections and mismatches, offers unique advantages to catalysts by altering their adsorption behavior through changes in the catalyst surface work function. This project focused on enhancing the electrocatalytic performance of shape-controlled nanocatalysts through deliberate synthesis design and advanced atomic-level surface engineering, achieving various nanocrystals (NCs) with precisely tuned lattice strain. The key findings and outcomes include (1) the development of a method to manipulate the atomic composition of Pt-based octahedral electrocatalyst by selectively extracting Ni atoms in the gas phase, altering the surface lattice strain to improve the performance of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), crucial in proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs); (2) the synthesis of core-shell structured electrocatalysts with controlled reduction kinetics between involved 3d-transition elements, increasing the lattice strain impact on the catalyst's surface to improve the activities of ORR and methanol electro-oxidation reaction (MOR) - important reactions in fuel cells, as well as oxygen evolution reaction (OER) - crucial reaction in water electrolyzers; and (3) an extensive investigation into ternary nanoalloy systems to understand the synergistic effects of lattice strain on electrocatalytic performance, achieved through precise synthesis control.

One notable achievement is the pioneering application of the CO gaseous etching method to octahedral Pt3Ni NCs, a class of highly effective electrocatalysts for the ORR. This process demonstrated the precise manipulation of surface composition, resulting in a unique nanostructure with a Pt-rich shell consisting of ~2 atomic layers through the removal of Ni atoms (Fig. 1a). As illustrated in Fig. 1b, this surface-engineered octahedral nanocatalyst exhibited a significant improvement in both mass activity (~1.8-fold) and specific activity (~2.2-fold) toward the ORR compared to its unmodified counterpart. After 20,000 potential cycles of durability tests, the surface-etched Pt−Ni nano-octahedral sample exhibited a mass activity of 1.50 A/mgPt, surpassing the initial mass activity of the unetched counterpart (1.40 A/mgPt) and outperforming the benchmark Pt/C by a factor of 8. This protocol holds promise for enhancing the ORR performance of various types of electrocatalysts.

Another significant accomplishment is the development of atomic-level core-shell structures in surface lattice-controlled nanocatalysts, leading to remarkable enhancements in both MOR and ORR. Through precise control of colloidal synthesis parameters such as reducing kinetics, deposition rate, and diffusion rate, we achieved a breakthrough in creating finely tuned core-shell structured nano-octahedra with lattice strain. Examples include octahedral CuNi@PtCu and octahedral PtCu@PtM (M = Co, Fe, Ni) nanocatalysts, which demonstrated outstanding MOR electrocatalytic activity (with a current density of peak value of ~4.7 mA cm-2, Fig. 1c) and exceptional ORR mass activity (18 times as high as that of the benchmarked Pt/C catalyst for the ORR at 0.90 V), respectively. Importantly, these achievements represent novel advancements not previously reported, and the synthesis methods showcased in this study offer new pathways for tailoring lattice strain in electrocatalysts by precisely controlling their shape, structure, and composition.

Based on these successful outcomes, we extensively analyzed the insights and knowledge acquired from our experimental investigations, resulting in the publication of over four review articles on lattice strain and its applications in esteemed journals such as Chem Rev. and Small (Fig. 1d). Moreover, this project has contributed to the academic literature with the publication of 20 peer-reviewed papers and the filling of one U.S. patent.

In summary, this project has made significant strides in advancing the development of catalytic sites with lattice strain, present in various types of shape-controlled state-of-the-art NCs as model systems. Through the creation and evaluation of their electrocatalytic performance in several typical energy-associated reactions such as ORR and OER, we conducted a comparative analysis of their performance with and without the strain stress. This enabled us to uncover a correlation between reactivity and strain, providing valuable guidelines for fine-tuning electrocatalytic activity. This Intellectual merit underscores the importance and impact of this project.

Regarding Broader Impacts, the success of this study has yielded multifold benefits to the general public through scientific discoveries and resultant technologies. Additionally, it has spurred the participation of junior researchers, contributed to Binghamton University's TAE initiative and NSF-supported STEM program, and facilitated novel curriculum development. Furthermore, this project fostered lab-based training activities for both graduate and undergraduate students. For instance, thanks to the support of this grant, two Ph.D. students were honored with the university's "Excellence Awards in Research", the highest graduate research accolades bestowed by the university. Moreover, two graduate students secured the "Clifford E Myers" Summer Research Awards. Notably, one undergraduate student received a prestigious award from the American Institute of Chemists, and one graduate student earned a postdoctoral fellowship from Los Alamos National Laboratory upon graduation, while two postdoctoral associates obtained professorships at Chongqing University (China) and SRMIST (SRM Institute of Science and Technology, India), respectively. The PI was elected and served as a Users' Executive Committee Member of Cornell High Energy Source (CHESS, Cornell University) up to 2020.

 


Last Modified: 04/29/2024
Modified by: Jiye Fang

Image
  • (a,b), Schematic illustration and ORR performance at 0.90 V vs. RHE of a CO-etched Pt3Ni octahedral nanocatalyst, respectively. (c), MOR activities of CuNi@PtCu nano-octahedra compared with the counterparts at 0.75 V vs. Ag/AgCl. (d), journal coverages of selected lattice-strain review articles.
    American Chemical Society 2023
    Copyrighted
    Jiye Fang
    Performance of novel electrocatalysts
